member.name: T:Smrf.AppLib.ArgumentChecker
member.summary: Contains methods that check method arguments and property values.
member.remarks:
This can be used by a class that wants to check values passed to its property setters and arguments passed to its methods. The CheckXXX() methods in this class throw an exception if a parameter value or method argument is invalid.
This class is marked internal to avoid compiler error CS0433 ("The type ... exists in both ...") when an executable references two or more assemblies that use this class.

member.name: M:Smrf.AppLib.ArgumentChecker.ThrowPropertyException(System.String,System.String,System.Exception)
member.overloads: Throws a new when the value passed to a property setter is invalid.
member.summary: Throws a new when the value passed to a property setter is invalid and there is an inner exception.
member.param: Name of the property calling this method.
Exception message details. Gets appended to the class and property names. See the example below.
Inner exception, or null if there is none.
member.remarks: Call this method when the value passed to a property setter is invalid. It throws an exception whose message automatically includes the class and property names.
member.example: If the class name that was passed to the constructor is "MyClass", is "MyProperty", and is "The value can't be null.", then the new exception's message is "MyClass.MyProperty: The value can't be null."

member.name: M:Smrf.AppLib.ArgumentChecker.ThrowPropertyException(System.String,System.String)

member.example: If the class name that was passed to the constructor is "MyClass", is "MyProperty", and is "The value can't be null.", then the new exception's message is "MyClass.MyProperty: The value can't be null."

member.summary: Utility methods for working with images in WPF.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Smrf.WpfGraphicsLib.WpfImageUtil.GetImageSynchronous(System.String)
member.summary: Synchronously gets an image from a specified URI and handles most errors by returning an error image.
member.param: The URI to get the image from. If the string is not a valid URI, an error image is returned.
member.returns: The specified image, or an error image if the specified image isn't available.
member.remarks:
There are two differences between using this method and using BitmapImage(URI):
If the URI is an URL, the image is downloaded synchronously instead of asynchronously.
If the image isn't available, an error image is returned instead of an exception being thrown.

member.name: M:Smrf.WpfGraphicsLib.WpfImageUtil.GetImageSynchronousIgnoreDpi(System.String)
member.summary: Synchronously gets an image from a specified URI, handles most errors by returning an error image, and ignores the DPI of the image.
member.param: The URI to get the image from. If the string is not a valid URI, an error image is returned.
member.returns: The specified image, or an error image if the specified image isn't available.
member.remarks:
There are three differences between using this method and using BitmapImage(URI):
If the URI is an URL, the image is downloaded synchronously instead of asynchronously.
If the image isn't available, an error image is returned instead of an exception being thrown.
If the image is marked with a DPI of something other than the screen resolution specified by , the marked DPI is ignored and the returned image will have a DPI of . For example, with a 96 DPI screen, a 100x100-pixel image with a DPI of 72 will be returned as a 100x100-WPF-unit image with a DPI of 96. This will cause the returned image to be displayed as 100x100 pixels.

member.name: M:Smrf.WpfGraphicsLib.WpfImageUtil.GetImageSynchronousHttp(System.Uri)
member.summary: Synchronously gets an image from a specified HTTP or HTTPS URI.
member.param: The URI to get the image from. Must be HTTP or HTTPS.
member.returns: The specified image.
member.remarks:
No error handling is performed by this method.
This differs from using BitmapImage(URI) in that the image is downloaded synchronously instead of asynchronously.

member.summary: Utility methods for working with WPF PathGeometry objects.

member.summary: Creates a PathGeometry from a sequence of points.

The other points in the sequence.

member.summary: Creates a PathGeometry that represents a diamond centered on a specified point.
member.param: The diamond's center.
One half the width of the diamond.
member.returns: A PathGeometry that represents the specified diamond. The PathGeometry is frozen.

member.name: M:Smrf.WpfGraphicsLib.WpfPathGeometryUtil.GetTriangle(System.Windows.Point,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates a PathGeometry that represents a triangle centered on a specified point.
member.param: The triangle's center.
One half the width of the square that bounds the triangle.
member.returns: A PathGeometry that represents the specified triangle. The PathGeometry is frozen.

member.name: M:Smrf.WpfGraphicsLib.WpfPathGeometryUtil.GetTaperedDiamond(System.Windows.Point,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates a PathGeometry that represents a diamond with inward-tapered edges, centered on a specified point.
member.param: The tapered diamond's center.
One half the width of the tapered diamond.
member.returns: A PathGeometry that represents the specified tapered diamond. The PathGeometry is frozen.

member.name: M:Smrf.WpfGraphicsLib.WpfPathGeometryUtil.GetRoundedX(System.Windows.Point,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates a PathGeometry that represents an X with outward-tapered edges, centered on a specified point.
member.param: The rounded X's center.
One half the width of the rounded X.
member.returns: A PathGeometry that represents the specified rounded X. The PathGeometry is frozen.

member.name: M:Smrf.WpfGraphicsLib.WpfPathGeometryUtil.GetCircleSegment(System.Windows.Point,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates a PathGeometry that represents a segment of a circle.
member.param: The circle's center.
The circle's radius. Must be greater than zero.
The angle of the segment, in radians. Must be between 0 and PI.
member.returns: A PathGeometry that represents the specified circle segment. The PathGeometry is frozen.
member.remarks:
The left radius of the sector points up. The right radius of the sector is clockwise from the left radius.
The line segments that form the circle segment will be stroked when the circle segment is drawn.

member.name: M:Smrf.WpfGraphicsLib.WpfPathGeometryUtil.GetQuadraticBezierCurve(System.Windows.Point,System.Windows.Point,System.Windows.Point)
member.summary: Gets a quadratic Bezier curve given the curve's endpoints and a Bezier control point.
member.param: The curve's start point.
The curve's endpoint.
The curve's Bezier control point.
member.returns: A new, frozen Bezier curve, as a PathGeometry.

member.name: M:Smrf.WpfGraphicsLib.WpfPathGeometryUtil.ReverseQuadraticBezierCurve(System.Windows.Media.PathGeometry)
member.summary: Duplicates and reverses a quadratic Bezier curve.
member.param: The quadratic Bezier curve to duplicate and reverse. This does not get modified.
member.returns: A new frozen, reversed Bezier curve, as a PathGeometry.
member.remarks: This method creates a new quadratic Bezier curve that uses the same control point as , but with the endpoints swapped.

member.name: M:Smrf.WpfGraphicsLib.WpfPathGeometryUtil.GetCurveThroughPoints(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Windows.Point},System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Gets a continuous curve through a specified set of points.
member.param: The points through which the curve will pass. Must contain at least two points.
Determines the amount of curvature. Can be any value, including negative values. Zero yields straight lines.
Determines the accuracy of the polyline approximation to a continuous curve. Each line segment in the polyline has a length of approximately tolerance WPF units. Must be greater than zero.
member.returns: A new frozen curve, as a PathGeometry.
member.remarks: This method and were adapted from Charles Petzold's article "Canonical Splines in WPF and Silverlight" at http://www.charlespetzold.com/blog/2009/01/ Canonical-Splines-in-WPF-and-Silverlight.html. The methods here are considerably simpler because they don't offer all of the features presented in the Peztold article.

member.name: M:Smrf.WpfGraphicsLib.WpfPathGeometryUtil.AddPointsToPolyLineSegment(System.Windows.Media.PolyLineSegment,System.Windows.Point,System.Windows.Point,System.Windows.Point,System.Windows.Point,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Adds points to a PolyLineSegment while getting a curve through a specified set of points.
member.param: The segment to add the points to.
The point preceding .
The start point for adding points.
The end point for adding points.
The point following .
Determines the amount of curvature. Can be any value, including negative values. Zero yields straight lines.
Determines the accuracy of the polyline approximation to a continuous curve. Each line segment in the polyline has a length of approximately tolerance WPF units. Must be greater than zero.
member.remarks: See for details on where this code came from.

true if the PathFigure that contains the PathSegment objects should be filled.
The PathSegment objects to use.
member.returns: A PathGeometry created from . The PathGeometry is frozen.

members.member: Determines the scale of the graph's vertices and edges.

member.name: P:Smrf.NodeXL.Visualization.Wpf.DrawerBase.GraphScale
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that determines the scale of the graph's vertices and edges.
member.value: A value that determines the scale of the graph's vertices and edges. Must be between and . The default value is 1.0.
member.remarks: If the value is anything besides 1.0, the graph's vertices and edges are shrunk while their positions remain the same. If it is set to 0.5, for example, the vertices are half their normal size and the edges are half their normal width. The overall size of the graph is not affected.

member.name: T:Smrf.NodeXL.Visualization.Wpf.EdgeDrawer
member.summary: Draws a graph's edges.
member.remarks:
This class is responsible for drawing a graph's edges. The default edge appearance is determined by this class's properties. The appearance of an individual edge can be overridden by adding appropriate metadata to the edge. The following metadata keys are honored:
The values of the and keys can be of type System.Windows.Media.Color or System.Drawing.Color.
If is true, an edge is drawn using or , depending on whether the edge has been marked as selected. If is false, is used regardless of whether the edge has been marked as selected.
When drawing the graph, call for each of the graph's edges.

members.member: Radius of a self-loop edge, which is drawn as a circle.

This is roughly the length of each line segment in the polyline approximation to a continuous curve used by DrawCurveThroughIntermediatePoints(), in WPF units. The smaller the number the smoother the curve, but the slower the performance.
Alpha value for the background of edge labels.

member.name: P:Smrf.NodeXL.Visualization.Wpf.EdgeDrawer.CurveStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies how edges are curved.
member.value: An value that specifies how edges are curved. The default is .
member.remarks:
If you set this property to EdgeCurveStyle., intermediate edge points should be stored on each edge using the ReservedMetadataKeys. key, and the key should be stored on the graph itself. If you are using the NodeXLControl, then the control automatically calculates and stores the intermediate edge points for you using an internal object. EdgeBundler "bundles" edges to reduce visual clutter.
If you set this property to EdgeCurveStyle. and you are not using the NodeXLControl, then you must calculate and store the intermediate edge points yourself. You can use an object to do this, or you can perform your own calculations.
Changing this property fires the event.

member.name: P:Smrf.NodeXL.Visualization.Wpf.EdgeDrawer.BezierDisplacementFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets a factor that determines the edge curvature when edges are drawn as Bezier curves.
member.value: A factor that determines the curvature of Bezier curves. Must be greater than or equal to zero.
member.remarks:
This is used only if is set to . It is the distance of the edge's Bezier control point from the midpoint of a straight line connecting the edge's endpoints, expressed as a multiple of the straight line's length.
If the value is zero, edges are drawn as straight lines. You can also specify that straight lines should be drawn by setting to .

member.name: T:Smrf.NodeXL.Visualization.Wpf.GraphDrawer
member.summary: Draws a NodeXL graph onto a collection of Visual objects.
member.remarks:
This is used to draw a NodeXL graph in a WPF application. It contains a collection of Visual objects that represent the graph's vertices and edges. Call to draw a laid-out NodeXL graph onto the contained .
does not lay out the graph. You should lay out the graph using one of the provided layout classes before calling .
A cannot be directly rendered and is typically not used directly by an application. Applications typically use one of two other NodeXL graph-drawing classes:
NodeXLControl, which is a FrameworkElement that wraps a and hosts its . NodeXLControl is meant for use in WPF desktop applications. It automatically lays out the graph before drawing it.
, which is a Visual that wraps a and hosts its . This is a lower-level alternative to NodeXLControl and can be used anywhere a Visual is more appropriate than a FrameworkElement. Like , does not lay out the graph before drawing it.
If you do use directly, rendering the graph requires a custom wrapper that hosts the GraphDrawer. object.

member.summary: Temporarily adds a caller-supplied Visual on top of the drawn graph.
member.param: The Visual to add on top of the graph.
member.remarks:
Call this method after calling to add a Visual on top of the graph. This is useful for adding a temporary tooltip, dragging marquee, or other Visual object to the graph.
The added Visual gets removed when is called again. You can also remove the Visual without redrawing the graph by calling .
An InvalidOperationException is thrown if the Visual has already been added.

member.remarks:

If the Visual doesn't exist in the VisualCollection, which will occur if was called after the Visual was added, this method does nothing.

member.name: P:Smrf.NodeXL.Visualization.Wpf.GroupDrawer.LabelScale
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that determines the scale of the group labels.
member.value: A value that determines the scale of the group labels. Must be between and . The default value is 1.0.
member.remarks:
If the value is anything besides 1.0, the group labels are shrunk while their positions remain the same. If it is set to 0.5, for example, the labels are half their normal size.
Group labels have their own scale, distinct from the used for other graph elements. That's because group labels should stay the same size in the NodeXLControl as the graph scale is changed, in which case the default value of 1.0 is used, but they should be scaled with other graph elements when an image of the graph is saved to a bitmap.

member.name: T:Smrf.NodeXL.Visualization.Wpf.VertexDrawer
member.summary: Draws a graph's vertices.
member.remarks:
This class is responsible for drawing a graph's vertices. The default vertex appearance is determined by this class's properties. The appearance of an individual vertex can be overridden by adding appropriate metadata to the vertex. The following metadata keys are honored:
If is true, a vertex is drawn using or , depending on whether the vertex has been marked as selected. If is false, is used regardless of whether the vertex has been marked as selected.
If a vertex has the shape and has the key, the vertex is drawn as a rectangle containing the text specified by the key's value. The default color of the text and the rectangle's outline is , but can be overridden with the key. The default fill color of the rectangle is , but can be overridden with the key.
If a vertex has a shape other than and has the key, the vertex is drawn as the specified shape, and the text specified by the key's value is drawn next to the vertex as an annotation at the position determined by .
If a vertex has the shape and has the key, the vertex is drawn as the image specified by the key's value.
The values of the and keys can be of type System.Windows.Media.Color or System.Drawing.Color.
When drawing the graph, call for each of the graph's vertices.

member.remarks: This method draws a fan motif's leaf vertices as a pie slice on top of the collapsed group vertex. The original part of the collapsed group vertex, which represents the fan motif's head vertex, is called the "head," and the part the represents the leaf vertices is called the "fan."

Minimum radius of a D-connector motif's span, in WPF units.
Maximum radius of a D-connector motif's span, in WPF units.

Minimum radius of a clique motif's rounded X, in WPF units. Scaling by Math.Sqrt(2) used to ensure the clique diagonal radius is the same as the D-connector motif span radius. However, the area of the clique rounded X is approximtely 26% larger due to convex vs. concave curves. To make areas equal multiply radius by approximately 0.6296404 instead.

Maximum radius of a clique motif's rounded X, in WPF units. Scaling by Math.Sqrt(2) used to ensure the clique diagonal radius is the same as the D-connector motif span radius. However, the area of the clique rounded X is approximtely 26% larger due to convex vs. concave curves. To make areas equal multiply radius by approximately 0.6296404 instead.
